head.title: Incommensurate and commensurate antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations in Câ¢r and Câ¢r-alloys from ab-initio dynamical spin susceptibility calculations

article.h1: Incommensurate and commensurate antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations in Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr and Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr-alloys from ab-initio dynamical spin susceptibility calculations

span.span: â€ Â Department of Physics, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4Â 7AL, U.K.
â€¡Â Department of Mathematics,Faculty of Science, Mahidol University,Bangkok 10400, Thailand.
Â¶Â Dipartimento di Fisica and Unita INFM, Universita di Messina, Italy
Â§Â Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Illinois, IL 61801, U.S.A.

div.p: A scheme for making ab-initio calculations of the dynamic paramagnetic spin susceptibilities of solids at finite temperatures is described. It is based on Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory and employs an electronic multiple scattering formalism. Incommensurate and commensurate anti-ferromagnetic spin fluctuations in paramagnetic Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr and compositionally disordered Câ¢r95â¢V5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95subscriptğ‘‰5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}V_{5} and Câ¢r95â¢Râ¢e5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95ğ‘…subscriptğ‘’5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}Re_{5} alloys are studied together with the connection with the nesting of their Fermi surfaces. We find that the spin fluctuations can be described rather simply in terms of an overdamped oscillator model. Good agreement with inelastic neutron scattering data is obtained.

Chromium is the archetypal itinerant anti-ferromagnet (AF) whose famous incommensurate spin density wave (SDW) ground state is determined by the nesting wave-vectors ğªnâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptğªğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n italic-e italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf q}_{nest} identified in the Fermi surface [1]. Chromium alloys also have varied AF properties [1] and their paramagnetic states have recently attracted attention owing, in part, to analogies drawn with the high temperature superconducting cuprates especially (Lâ¢acâ¢Sâ¢r1-c)2â¢Câ¢uâ¢O4subscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘2ğ¶ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‚4OPEN:( italic-L italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C italic-u italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(La_{c}Sr_{1-c})_{2}CuO_{4}. The incommensurate SDW fluctuations in these materials [2] are rather similar to those seen in the paramagnetic phase of Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr close to TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N}. Moreover â€˜parentâ€™ materials Lâ¢a2â¢Câ¢uâ¢O4ğ¿subscriptğ‘2ğ¶ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‚4italic-L italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C italic-u italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endLa_{2}CuO_{4} in the one instance and Câ¢r95â¢Mâ¢n5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95ğ‘€subscriptğ‘›5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-M italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}Mn_{5} or Câ¢r95â¢Râ¢e5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95ğ‘…subscriptğ‘’5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}Re_{5} in the other are simple commensurate AF materials which on lowering the electron concentration by suitable doping develop incommensurate spin fluctuations which may be promoted by imperfectly nested Fermi surfaces.

Here we examine the nature of damped diffusive spin fluctuations in chromium above the NeeÂ´Â´ğ‘’OVERACCENT:acute ARG:start italic-e ARG:end\acute{e}l temperature TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} which are precursory to the SDW ground state. We also study dilute chromium alloys, Câ¢r95â¢Râ¢e5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95ğ‘…subscriptğ‘’5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}Re_{5} and Câ¢r95â¢V5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95subscriptğ‘‰5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}V_{5} and obtain good agreement with experimental data. For example, recent inelastic neutron scattering experiments [1, 3] have measured incommensurate AF â€˜paramagnonsâ€™, persisting up to high frequencies in the latter system. We explore the temperature dependence, variation with dopant concentration and the evolution of the spin fluctuations in these systems from incommensurability to commensurability with increasing frequency and provide the first ab-initio description of these effects. To this end we describe a new scheme for calculating the wave-vector and frequency dependent dynamic spin susceptibility of metals which is based on the Time Dependent Density Functional Theory (TDDFT) of Gross et al. [4] and as such is an all electron theory. For the first time the temperature dependent dynamic spin susceptibility of metals and alloys is calculated from this basis. There have been several simple parameterised models to describe the magnetic properties of Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr and its alloys [7]. All of these have concentrated on the approximately nested electron â€˜jackâ€™ and slightly larger octahedral hole pieces of the Fermi surface [1] and, at best, have only included the effects of all the remaining electrons via an electron reservoir. We find similarities between our results and results from such models but show that a complete picture is obtained only when an electronic band-filling effect which favors a simple AF ordering at low temperature is also considered. We also find that the spin fluctuations are given an accurate description as overdamped diffusive simple harmonic oscillator modes which are at the heart of theories of the effects of spin fluctuations upon the properties of itinerant electron systems [5].

Over the past few years great progress has been made in establishing TDDFT [4]. Analogs of the Hohenberg-Kohn [8] theorem of the static density functional formalism have been proved and rigorous properties found. Here we consider a paramagnetic metal subjected to a small, time-dependent external magnetic field, ğ›â¢(ğ«,t)ğ›ğ«ğ‘¡bold-b OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:){\bf b}({\bf r},t) which induces a magnetisation ğ¦â¢(ğ«,t)ğ¦ğ«ğ‘¡bold-m OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:){\bf m}({\bf r},t) and use TDDFT to derive an expression for the dynamic paramagnetic spin susceptibility Ï‡â¢(ğª,w)ğœ’ğªğ‘¤italic-chi OPEN:( bold-q PUNCT:, italic-w CLOSE:)\chi({\bf q},w) via a variational linear response approach [6]. Accurate calculations of dynamic susceptibilities from this basis are scarce (e.g. [9]) because they are difficult and computationally demanding. The Green function can be obtained within the framework of multiple scattering (KKR) theory [11]. This makes this formalism applicable to disordered alloys as well as ordered compounds and elemental metals, the disorder being treated by the Coherent Potential Approximation (CPA) [12]. Some of these features also emerge qualitatively from the simple parameterised models based on that part of the band-structure near Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu which leads to the nested electron and hole octahedra at the Fermi surface [7]. Our â€˜first-principlesâ€™ calculations, being based on an all-electron theory, however, need some additional interpretation. As analysed by recent total energy calculations [16], b.c.c. Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr with the experimentally measured lattice spacing tends to form a commensurate AF phase at low temperatures which is modulated by a spin density wave of appropriate wavelength. The overall AF instability of the paramagnetic phase is promoted by the approximate half-filling of the narrow 3d-bands [17] which is further modified by a weak perturbation coming from the Fermi surface nesting. As dopants such as Vğ‘‰italic-VV and Râ¢eğ‘…ğ‘’italic-R italic-eRe are added not only is the Fermi surface nesting altered but also the d-bands become either further from or closer to being half-filled.

The calculations can be summarised in terms of the damped oscillator model. Near TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} the magnetic fluctuations have their greatest weight around the ğªnâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptğªğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n italic-e italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf q}_{nest}. At higher Tğ‘‡italic-TT the peak diminishes and weight grows at ğªğªbold-q{\bf q}â€™s nearer {0,0,1}001OPEN:{ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:}\{0,0,1\} reflecting the shift in the peak in Iâ¢mâ¢Ï‡â¢(ğª,ğª,w)ğ¼ğ‘šğœ’ğªğªğ‘¤italic-I italic-m italic-chi OPEN:( bold-q PUNCT:, bold-q PUNCT:, italic-w CLOSE:)Im\chi({\bf q},{\bf q},w) from ğªnâ¢eâ¢sâ¢tsubscriptğªğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n italic-e italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf q}_{nest} to commensurate ğªğªbold-q{\bf q}â€™s with increase in frequency wğ‘¤italic-ww. If the frequency cutoff is reduced, <m2â¢(ğª)>expectationsuperscriptğ‘š2ğªRELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than<m^{2}({\bf q})> near {0,0,1}001OPEN:{ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:}\{0,0,1\} is sharply diminished so that the Brillouin zone integral of <m2â¢(ğª)>expectationsuperscriptğ‘š2ğªRELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than<m^{2}({\bf q})>, <m2>expectationsuperscriptğ‘š2RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than<m^{2}>, decreases with increasing temperature as inferred from neutron scattering data [1].

We have not included the effects of spin fluctuation interactions i.e. mode-mode coupling [18] into our calculations and have determined TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} and the static susceptibility by what is essentially an ab-initio Stoner theory. In weak itinerant ferromagnets, for example, mode-mode coupling causes a dramatic suppression of the Curie temperatures from those estimated from a Stoner theory. For the Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr systems studied here, the fair agreement with experiment which we obtain for TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} and the relatively large value of the damping factor Î“â¢(ğª)Î“ğªGamma OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)\Gamma({\bf q}) with respect to that in weakly itinerant ferromagnets, is suggestive that such spin fluctuation effects are small. Spin fluctuation calculations have, however, been carried out by Hasegawa and others for simple parameterised models of Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr neglecting Stoner particle-hole excitations and Fermi surface nesting [19]. Using a functional integral technique he made a high temperature (static) approximation so that all the thermally induced fluctuations were treated classically and found TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} for commensurate AF order to be 370K and <m2>expectationsuperscriptğ‘š2italic-square-root ARG:start RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ARG:end\sqrt{<m^{2}>} to increase linearly with temperature above TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N}. A quantitative calculation, however, in which the Stoner particle-hole excitations and spin fluctuations are treated within the same framework is needed to determine unequivocally whether or not a Stoner-like picture is adequate for these systems.

In summary, we have presented a first-principles framework for the calculation of dynamic paramagnetic spin susceptibilities of metals and their alloys at finite temperatures. At this point we add that the approach can also be applied to the study of magnetic excitations in magnetically ordered materials. The first applications on the AF spin fluctuations in Câ¢rğ¶ğ‘Ÿitalic-C italic-rCr and Câ¢r95â¢Râ¢e5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95ğ‘…subscriptğ‘’5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}Re_{5} above TNsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{N} and in paramagnetic Câ¢r95â¢V5ğ¶subscriptğ‘Ÿ95subscriptğ‘‰5italic-C italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:95 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCr_{95}V_{5} have found good agreement with available experimental data.
